content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Role playing gamers and dice lovers will appreciate this problem. For the others, it is still an interesting challenge that can be solved with basic probability knowledge.

Maybe add the formula to calculate the average because it's not in any way implied by the statement. Since this is for CoC, everything should be clear in the statement, so that people don't have to search elsewhere to find a solution. Otherwise, a great and fun puzzle.

I would like to approve the contribution, but there are two points that I find problematic.

Suggestion: replace the term "average result" by "average of the lowest and highest value the dice can roll".
Suggestion: either unify the type of the answers (require the decimal point .0 even when the answer is an int) and specify type float ; or make clear in the Output section that the result should not have a decimal point when it is an integer. Or you could maybe even make the dices odd, to force the result to be an integer. That would solve the floating point problems.

Explanation:

The first is, as previously said by some comments, about how the 'average result' does not clearly signify that it is computed as (<high>+1)/2. The formulation is clumsy, as I think you use "average" as a synonym of "mathematical expectation". An average is generally defined on a series of values/samples. Here, what you want is the notion of expectation, the average over an infinite amount of dice rolls. 

This is a problem, 1) because it requires mathematical knowledge that isn't directly linked to programming ability, so generally unfair. 2) because there is no values to explicitely average. The coder must look at the test cases and deduce that the notion you refer to is the mathematical expectation, or more simply the average of the lower and higher dice result.

For the second suggestion, it is simply a case of formating not being completely specified outside of the test cases. Also, rounding floating points isn't an exact science so caution is advised.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like this idea, the problem can't be resolved in 1 line and has enough complexity for a CoC

it's complicated to understand the 1d6 => 6+1/2 * 1
why not just do 6/2*1

I like dice, and this is a nice exercise for dice fans. I really appreciate it.
I made a mistake on the "-" processing (bad copy-and-paste).
Just a remark: I was surprise not to found any output in the auto-generated code. Isn't it the usage to have somme dummy output so that we understand what fonction we should use (ex: console.log() rather than console.error() in JavaScript) ?
On a side note, I would love to see an evolution of it, perhaps as a classic puzzle, where you have to compute the number of occurrences of each outcome (so that people understand that 2d6 is not the same thing than 1d6*2).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I tried it, didn't encouter problems and is a cool puzzle

Liked it, I forgot to handle the '*' modifier and was not sure at first how to handle it, so maybe an example with this modifier is appreaciated, like "1d6*2 means twice the dice value. Note that the * modifier is not cumulated with + or - modifier".

Also the first line is not used when we know that we just have to split with space. Maybe you keep it for C, I don't know.

Finally, I often see that we have to round the result, maybe to prevent floating number that can be displayed differently depending on language. Maybe we should have to round or floor the output.
